item.content:encoded:
Last fall, my dad spent a few days with me while he was in town (then Mankato, MN) for meetings. We ended up having some really interesting conversations one evenings. I’d like to share some of that discussion, only a few months late.

A little background: my dad is non-techie. He is pretty limited to reading and writing emails, and even that was a stretch at first. So that makes his observation a little more interesting, at least to me.

But on that evening, we somehow got on a few technical topics. After awhile, my dad made an interesting observation, comparing the internet to the human brain.

A little more background, a few years my dad had brain surgery to remove a tumor. So that explains some of his interest in the brain.

Anyways, we went on to other topics, including finding his former college roommate on LinkedIn. But I returned to his comment about the brain and the internet as I trying to fall asleep that night. And I realized he had a good point. The internet shares behavior with the human brain.

When a route on the internet gets really slow or fails all together, traffic will adjust its flow to use faster paths to their destination. This could be called self-healing.

In a similar fashion, the brain also self-heals. If a pathway is blocked because a neuron has died, then the other neurons will try to find another pathway. Or in the extreme case of brain surgery, entire sections of the brain will re-wire themselves.

While technological advances are amazing, it’s more amazing to think about similar processes that have always been a part of us.
